Award.AwardTitle: Photochemical Delivery and Metal Mediated Reactions of Bioactive Small Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is now well established that the gaseous molecules nitric oxide, carbon monoxide and carbon disulfide are important regulators of many biological functions in mammals and, more specifically, in humans. For examples, nitric oxide is a regulator of blood pressure, while nitric oxide, carbon monoxide, and sulfur compounds such as carbon disulfide have key, but still poorly understood, roles in wound healing and inflammation. The continuing research represented by this project encompasses two related topics. The first is concerned with elucidating the fundamental chemistry that defines the physiology of these species, while the second is concerned with designing new technology to deliver such bioactive small molecules (BSMs) to specific biological targets on demand. The former topic involves the application of modern instrumentation to examine rates of the chemical reactions of these BSMs with biologically relevant metal centers, while the latter is focused on utilizing light as a trigger for controlling the timing, location and dosage of BSM release at specific sites. Graduate and undergraduate student researchers in these projects acquire interdisciplinary training in micro- and nano-materials science, chemical biology, photochemistry and chemical synthesis and kinetics. They also are active in K-12 outreach activities, where they share the excitement of their research activities with teachers and students in local schools.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the NSF Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Peter C. Ford from the University of California, Santa Barbara for interdisciplinary investigations into new strategies and precursors for photochemical delivery of the BSMs NO and CO to physiological targets and for exploratory studies into delivery of the potentially bioactive molecule CS2. Experimental methods will include syntheses of conjugates between BSM precursors and chromophores including organic dyes and nano-materials for one- and 2-photon excitation. Modern optical methods (ultra-fast laser studies, confocal microscopy, etc.) will evaluate quantitative photosensitization mechanisms and provide guidelines for design optimization, while in vitro (cell culture) studies provide initial tests of biological viability. In collaborative studies, the investigators will explore polymer-based nano- and micro-carriers for delivery of BSM precursor-chromophore conjugates to specific biological sites. The principles thus defined should be broadly applicable to delivery of other bioactive molecules. In addition, stopped-flow and flash photolysis kinetics spectroscopy, computations and collaborative low temperature matrix studies will be used to elucidate fundamental mechanisms of BSM reactions with biologically relevant metal-centered substrates. Evaluating such pathways is crucial to defining the chemistry/physiology relationships of these complex systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes report for NSF

      The simple diatomic molecules nitric oxide (NO) and carbon monoxide (CO) are important regulators of mammalian physiological functions such as blood pressure (NO) and wound healing (CO & NO). The research accomplished over the course of this grant had two themes: 1) developing new interdisciplinary strategies for the targeted release of NO and CO at specific physiological sites and 2) elucdating the chemical biology of NO with biolgically relevant metal centers. A third theme was to initiate studies into determining whether another compound carbon disulfide (CS2) is similarly a small molecule bioregulator (SMB). 

      Photochemical release (uncaging) of SMBs could have a major impact as a method for delivering these regulators in biomedical applications, since this method offers control of timing, location and dosage. We thus initiated fundamental studies of two major problems with this strategy, namely, the relatively poor transmision of visible light through tissue, and the need to deliver the caged SMBs to the desired targets before activating with light. We addressed these issues by coupling SMB precursors with antennas that capture tissue-penetrating near infrared (NIR) light and by pairing these conjugates with biological mechanisms such as macrophages and cell-specific targeting peptides. Modern optical, reaction kinetics and cellular biology methods were used to evaluate the success of photosensitization mechanisms and to develop guidelines for optimizing this approach.

      With regard to other themes, we studied quantitatively the reaction of NO with iron(II) ions and the amino acid cysteine in aqueous media. The product is a dinitrosyl iron complex (DNIC) that has been argued to serve as an in vivo NO carrier in mammalian chemical biology.  We presented, for the first time, a logical mechanism by which DNICs are formed under physiologically relevant conditions. We also developed new compounds that release CS2 with controlled rates in aqueous media and initiated exploratory studies with a collaborator to evaluate the effects of this SMB on the relaxation of cerebral arteries.  The jury is still out whether CS2 is a bioregulator that is produced by native pathways.

      The intellectual merit of these investigations was derived from advances in elucidating the fundamental mechanisms by which SMBs can be transported and then photochemically uncaged from conjugates of precursors and nanoparticle antennas.  We have also shown that living macrophage immune cells can be recruited as Trojan Horses to transport polymer-based nano- and micro-carriers of such conjugates. Most importantly, these strategies are not confined to NO and CO but should be broadly applicable to the targeted uncaging of any bioactive small molecule. Furthermore, we anticipate that the exploratory studies initiated with carbon disulfide could prove extremely rich, given the possibility that directed CS2 release would be a valuable tool for more in-depth investigations and may have therapeutic value.

            This project has served as a platform for educating graduate, undergraduate & postdoctoral students and shorter-term visitors from other US and foreign institutions. The quantitative, interdisciplinary reasoning applied to diverse chemical problems provided an intellectually stimulating educational experience. Group members regularly report their research at scientific conferences. They are also actively involved in outreach programs such as discussions with HS classes regarding the accessibility of careers in science to raise scientific literacy in the schools and the community. This integrated training prepares these early career researchers to contribute effectively not only to the scientific workforce but also to their future communities.

            There is a complex interplay of small molecule bioregulators in pathophysiological states such as oxidative stress and inflammation that is not yet fully understood. Thus, novel technology to uncage these SMBs with temporal-spatial precision will allow one to elicit specific physiological responses, thereby providing new tools for elucidating these responses. Furthermore, while treating disease states was not the goal, we anticipate that the uncaging strategies developed in our laboratory will provide new photochemical methodologies for medical applications.  We are currently preparing intellectual property disclosures with the UCSB Office of Technology to encourage commercial development
